Macron makes state visit to UK in attempt to move past Brexit
subhead: French President Emmanuel Macron is visiting the United Kingdom on Tuesday, where he will meet with the royal family and Prime Minister Keir Starmer. It is the first state visit by the leader of a member of the European Union since the Brexit crisis of 2020.
byline: By Cécile Ducourtieux (London, correspondent) and Philippe Ricard

title: At least 10 dead and hundreds arrested in Kenya during anti-government protests
subhead: Journalists saw running battles on Monday on the outskirts of Nairobi, as anti-riot police fired tear gas at small gatherings. Some protesters responded by throwing rocks and engaging in looting and vandalism.

title: In southern Gaza, the doctors at Nasser Hospital face a fierce struggle
subhead: Medical staff at the major hospital, located in an area gripped by chaos, are having to cope with both a shortage of medical supplies and a daily influx of wounded people.

title: 'French women have been free to open bank accounts for 60 years, but they still struggle to achieve financial independence'
subhead: Women in France have had the right to open a bank account without their husband's permission for 60 years, since July 13, 1965. But the financial independence so desired by French women, according to a July 7 study, has yet to be achieved, explains Le Monde's Isabelle Chaperon in her column.

title: Tax on ultra-rich: 'France has the opportunity to lead the way,' say Nobel Prize-winning economists
subhead: As public deficits balloon and extreme wealth explode, creating a minimum tax on the assets of billionaires should be a priority, argue seven Nobel Prize-winning economists in an op-ed for Le Monde.

Putin's choice of a long war in Ukraine
subhead: The suspension of American aid to Kyiv fits neatly into the Russian leader's military plans: to intensify his offensive in Ukraine this summer, and to sustain an endless conflict, now synonymous with the survival of his regime through a newfound 'stability' built on a war economy.

title: In Bosnia and Herzegovina, stone treasures, canyons and cypress trees await
subhead: The Balkan country, with its painful past, is rich in historical sites and mountainous landscapes − from the Kravica Waterfalls to the Olympic sites of Sarajevo, from a medieval fortress to Tito's bunker.

title: The relentless rush to build dams in China's Tiger Leaping Gorge: 'If we lose our land, we lose everything'
subhead: 'The Himalayas Overheating' (5/6). In the far southwest of China, plans to build massive reservoirs as part of hydroelectric dam projects have condemned dozens of mountain villages to disappear.
byline: By Harold Thibault (Tiger Leaping Gorge (China), special correspondent)
